clinical_study.brief_title: Soccer and Health: Diet and Exercise on Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
clinical_study.official_title: Soccer and Health: Impact of Nutritional Intervention and Recreational Soccer Training in Patients With Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

clinical_study.source: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: The present study aims to evaluate the impact of a soccer training program lasting 12 weeks in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. 60 sedentary adults and elderly patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (age: 50-75 y), with a BMI > 25kg/m2 and > 29kg/m2, respectively, from the Hospital of the Medical Faculty of São Paulo University will participate in this study. They will be randomly divided in 3 groups (soccer, running and control). All patients will undergo the following assessments: anthropometric, dietary, physical performance, inflammatory, metabolic and hormonal parameters such as gene expression, bone markers and predictors of cardiovascular disease. In addition the investigators aim to evaluate the body composition of these patients by DXA, and muscle and visceral lipids content by proton spectroscopic MRI.

primary_outcome.measure: Attenuation of expression of proinflammatory genes verified by qPCR-array technique ranging from at least 5% in pre and post-intervention measurements

secondary_outcome.measure: Enhance physical performance verified by oxygen consumption measurement on treadmill

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: patients with diabetes type 2 diabetes, up to 15 years in duration, HbA1c from 6.5 to 11.0%, with none administration of insulin.
Exclusion Criteria: patients with BMI lower (<) than 25 kg/m2 and higher (>) than 48 kg/m2, blood pressure > 160/100 mm Hg, fasting triglyceride levels of> 500 mg / dL, proteinuria> 100 mg / dL, serum creatinine> 1.5 mg / dL, liver complications, neuropathy or advanced retinopathy, macroangiopathy, diabetic foot, or any other serious health condition that impairs their adherence to the training protocol satisfactorily.
